title: brexit news express poll second Brexit vote theresa may leadership
story: According to the ComRes poll of 2,000 adults for the Sunday Express 53 per cent have rejected the idea of a so called People&rsquos Vote and instead want Theresa May to get on with the job of leaving the EU. Voters polled also made it clear they do not want a general election with 50 per cent opposing another immediate vote for parliament and only 26 per cent backing the idea. Crucially, the poll also reveals that the efforts by Remainers to scare voters away from supporting no deal with the EU have failed.                Brexit deal opinion polls latest: THIS is how British public feel                Theresa May VS Boris Johnson: Poll reveals who Britons prefer as PMAsked about their concerns with Brexit, 50 per cent said they were not worried about free travel to Europe, 47 per cent not worried about a shortage of medicines, and 54 per cent unconcerned about a shortage of food.Tory MP Peter Bone, the founder of the pro-Brexit Grassroots Out campaign group, said: &ldquoThis poll just proves what I am finding on the door step and in my mail.&ldquoNobody is writing or asking me for a second referendum, there is no real support for it out there.Prime Minister Theresa May holds a news conference at Downing Street (Image:  Ian VoglerPool via Reuters)47 per cent not worried about a shortage of medicines (Image: Matt CardyGetty Images)&ldquoYou have to wonder what it would even achieve. The real people&rsquos vote was in 2016 when we voted to leave the EU.&ldquoIf we had a second one and the Remainers lost they would claim it was unfair and want another one and then another until they won.&ldquoThere is clearly no appetite for a second referendum or for changing the result and it is obvious that the Remainers&rsquo project fear messages are not getting through either.61 per cent prefer current PM Theresa May over Boris Johnson, former Foreign Secretary (Image:  EPAANDY RAIN)Jacob William Rees-Mogg (Image: Jack TaylorGetty Images)There was also strong support for Mrs May continuing as Prime Minister until the Leave date on 29th March 2019 with 47 per cent wanting her to stay in office until then.There was little support for Mrs May stepping aside for her main rivals in the party with 61 per cent preferring her over Boris Johnson, 48 per cent over Jacob Rees-Mogg, 58 per cent over environment secretary Michael Gove and 54 per cent over foreign secretary Jeremy Hunt.                'Get us OUT!' Furious Brexiteers urge May to ditch 'RUBBISH' planHe said: &ldquoI urged people to go out and lobby their MPs and tell them if they don't vote this deal down that they won't reelect them. I stand by that.&ldquoI have had a lot of support from members with letters and emails and people saying that I had inspired them.But Cllr Perry said that he has come under pressure from party bosses but vowed to not be stopped from speaking out.He said: &ldquoNumber 10 and CCHQ obviously didn't like what I have been saying. I have had it from good authority to suggest that I should not be so vocal but I will not be silenced.Cllr Perry added: &ldquoThis deal has to be voted down. It is the worst thing that could happen for this country so I don't take back anything I have said.

title: brexit news theresa may brexit deal latest eu immigration
story: Defying the party critics attempting to oust her, the Prime Minister is to set out her belief that the draft Brexit agreement will give her Government the power to end the open door to EU migrants and introduce a skills-based immigration system.&nbsp&ldquoWe want an immigration system for the future that everyone can have confidence in, she will say in a keynote speech to business leaders.                You say: &lsquoNo&rsquo to second Brexit vote and &lsquoyes&rsquo Theresa May                Brexit news: Barnier plans to lock UK into EU until DECEMBER 2022Once we have left the EU, we will be fully in control of who comes here.Mrs May's determination to move the debate about the Brexit deal onto the crucial issue of immigration comes after she warned the Tory MPs attempting to drive her out of Downing Street that their plotting could put the entire Brexit process at risk.And her drive to face down the backbench Brexiteer coup was given a significant boost when it was confirmed that her foes were struggling to collect the 48 supporters needed to trigger a no-confidence vote in her leadership. Their hopes of a vote as early as today appeared to be evaporating over the weekend.PM Theresa May is insisting her Brexit deal will give us back the control of our borders (Image: BEN STANSALLAFPGetty Images)Dominic Raab resigned his role of Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union last week (Image: TOLGA AKMENAFPGetty Images)Sir Graham Brady, chairman of the ruling body of Tory backbenchers and custodian of the letters demanding a confidence ballot, said that the threshold had not been reached.He also predicted it would be very likely the Prime Minister would win such a vote.By last night, only 25 Tory MPs had openly confirmed they had written to Sir Graham demanding a confidence vote in her leadership.Mrs May will today use a speech at the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) conference in central London to argue that her Brexit deal will deliver the key demands of millions of voters in the 2016 EU referendum for the country to regain control of borders, law making and billions of pounds of taxpayers' money a year.She is expected to say: &ldquoWe now have an intense week of negotiations ahead of us in the run-up to the special European Council on Sunday.&ldquoDuring that time I expect us to hammer out the full and final details of the framework that will underpin our future relationship and I am confident that we can strike a deal at the council that I can take back to the House of Commons.&ldquoThe core elements of that deal are already in place.The Withdrawal Agreement has been agreed in full, subject of course to final agreement being reached on the future framework.End the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (Image: Becker &amp Bredelullstein bild via Getty Images)&ldquoThat Agreement is a good one for the UK. It fulfills the wishes of the British people as expressed in the 2016 referendum.I have always had a very clear sense of the outcomes I wanted to deliver for people in these negotiations - control over our borders, by bringing an end to free movement, once and for all control of our money, so we can decide for ourselves how to spend it, and can do so on priorities like our NHS control of our laws, by ending the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice in the United Kingdom and ensuring that our laws are made and enforced here in this country.Turning to migration, the Prime Minister will add: &ldquoGetting back full control of our borders is an issue of great importance to the British people.The United Kingdom is a country that values the contribution that immigration has made to our society and economy over many years.End to free movement of people (Image: Leon NealGetty Images)&ldquoAnd in the future, outside the EU, immigration will continue to make a positive contribution to our national life.&ldquoBut the difference will be this: once we have left the EU, we will be fully in control of who comes here.&ldquoIt will no longer be the case that EU nationals, regardless of the skills or experience they have to offer, can jump the queue ahead of engineers from Sydney or software developers from Delhi. Instead of a system based on where a person is from, we will have one that is built around the talents and skills a person has to offer.&ldquoNot only will this deliver on the verdict of the referendum. It should lead to greater opportunity for young people in this country to access training and skilled employment.E-gates for visitors from the USA, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, and Canada (Image: Oli ScarffGetty Images)We want an immigration system for the future that everyone can have confidence in. Yes, a system that works for business.One that allows us to attract the brightest and the best from around the world, more streamlined application and entry processes.&ldquoAnd we are already talking action in that regard, introducing e-gates for visitors from the USA, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, and Canada.&ldquoBut it also needs to command the confidence of the public by putting them in control of who comes to this country. That is what I am determined to deliver, and I look forward to working with you to achieve it.Theresa May will meet EU President Jean-Claude Juncker this week (Image: Roni RekomaaBloomberg via Getty Images)Mrs May came out fighting against her Tory critics in an interview on Sky News yesterday.She used the interview to warn that the Brexiteer attempt to topple her could backfire by undermining the country's departure from the EU.A change of leadership at this point isn't going to make the negotiations any easier and it isn't going to change the parliamentary arithmetic.What it will do is bring in a degree of uncertainty. That is uncertainty for people and their jobs.Theresa May is due to head to Brussels to meet EU leaders and discuss further her Brexit deal (Image: Jasper JuinenBloomberg via Getty Images)What it will do is mean that it is a risk that we delay the negotiations and that is a risk that Brexit gets delayed or frustrated, Mrs May said.She confirmed she will head to Brussels this week for talks with EU President Jean-Claude Juncker to finalise a draft declaration outlining the UK's future relationship with the bloc.Anticipating a critical week in the negotiations, she said: I will be going back to Brussels.The negotiating teams are working as we speak and obviously which day I go back to Brussels will partly be about how those negotiations go.Tory and Brexiteer: Jacob Rees-Mogg  (Image: Dan KitwoodGetty Images)I will be going back to Brussels, I will be in touch with other leaders as well, because the summit next week - and it is next week - this special European Council, will be among the European leaders.Mrs May also insisted she had not considered quitting after the backbench coup attempt led by Jacob Rees-Mogg was unleashed last week.Asked if she had considered stepping down, the Prime Minister said: No I haven't. Of course it has been a tough week, actually these negotiations have been tough right from the start, but they were always going to get even more difficult right toward the end when we are coming to that conclusion.EU sources last night claimed to have squeezed further concessions out of the UK in technical talks about the declaration on the future relationship.British fishery has been a big concern over the past few months (Image: English HeritageHeritage ImagesGetty Images)One diplomat claimed Brussels officials had inserted extra rules protecting the right of European fishing vessels to fish in UK waters and curbing Britain's chances of gaining an economic advantage over EU rivals.But a Downing Street source said: In the final days of the negotiations, Brussels will continue to do what it always does in leaking claims about what has been achieved. These claims need to be taken with a pinch of salt.Mrs May is also expected to face down demands from a gang of five Brexiteer ministers to press for final changes to her withdrawal agreement.Michael Gove was expected to meet with fellow Eurosceptics Andea Leadsom, Penny Mordaunt, Chris Grayling and Liam Fox over breakfast this morning to discuss a last-ditch push to alter the deal.But Whitehall insiders expect to the Prime Minister to insist that the withdrawal agreement has been agreed and cannot be rewritten.

title: house of lords cap size peers bernard jenkin westminster
story: Sir Bernard Jenkin, chairman of the Public Administration and Constitutional Affairs Committee (PACAC), wants the number of Lords cut and capped at 600 instead of the current 800. The report from the PACAC has called for urgent action and backs previous findings from the Burns report, which laid out proposals on reducing the size of the House of Lords. It argues the growing size of the Chamber is impacting on its ability to function as effectively as it should.                Peer demolishes second referendum bid with THIS point about 2016 vote                Tory peer TEARS into Barnier during heated Brexit debateConservative MP Sir Bernard said Westminster&rsquos revising Chamber must not be allowed to grow &ldquoexponentially and axing the 200 peers over the coming years was the &ldquoobvious step.He said: The House of Lords is of vital importance to the UK's political system, carrying out important scrutiny and revising functions, but it is a problem that the size of the Chamber continues to grow exponentially.My Committee is calling for the number of peers to be reduced, and then capped, at 600, as recommended in the Burns report.This is an urgent window of opportunity and the Government and other party leaders must seize this moment of consensus to ensure the number of peers is reduced to 600 over the years ahead.Sir Bernard Jenkin wants the number of peers in the House of Lords capped at 600 (Image: )The committee of MPs have highlighted how the reduction rate proposed in the Burns report would take up to 11-years to implement.It has called for party leaders to agree to strict retirement targets in order to accelerate reaching the new target.MPs said a sharp fall in numbers could be achieved with a commitment from Prime Minister Theresa May following a &ldquotwo-out-one-in policy.They have also called for a body to justify new appointments to the Chamber, which would be allocated to pparties based on their vote share in the most recent general election.Sir Bernard, the MP for Harwich and North Essex since the 2010 general election, has also laid out plans for a new 15-year term for newly-appointed peers.                Labour peer MOCKS organisers of second Brexit referendum marchMPs said the fall in peers could be achieved by Theresa May following a two-out-one-in policy (Image: )He said this was a &ldquodesirable but not essential part of the recommended reform, but also described it as &ldquoperhaps the most radical element of the scheme.The PACAC chairman added: &ldquoThe introduction of 15-year term limits for new life peers is perhaps the most radical element of the scheme and it will immediately create two classes of peer with all existing peers remaining appointed for life, and all new peers for a fixed term.There are members of both Houses who have been highly effective parliamentarians for far longer than 15 years, and this fixed term could remove peers at the peak of their effectiveness.But Sir Bernard said the proposals outlined by the committee would just be &ldquoa minimal incremental reform and &ldquowill fall far short of the aspirations of many who wish to see abolition or an elected Upper House.Sir Bernard Jenkin said the proposals would just be a minimal incremental reform  (Image: )He concluded: Adopting this reform does, however, not remove the pressure for more fundamental reform of the second chamber.A spokesman for the Lord Speaker&rsquos Committee said: We are pleased the Commons Public Administration and Constitutional Affairs Committee have recognised the importance of the Burns committee recommendations to reduce the size of the House of Lords.We welcome their agreement that a capped membership of 600 is appropriate and new Members be appointed on a 'two-out, one-in' formula in line with general election results.In the first year since the Burns report was published, the House of Lords has met the recommended targets in reducing the size of the House but it is important that progress is maintained.

title: prince charles birthday pictures prince louis princess charlotte meghan markle royal news
story: Playful Prince Charles - Images are part of a set to mark His Royal Highness's 70th birthday (Image: Chris JacksonGetty Images for Clarence House)Released to mark Prince Charles&rsquo 70th birthday, the heartwarming snaps give a private insight into all aspects of his life.&nbspThe camera has captured the heir to the throne behind the scenes of royal life, looking happy and relaxed, laughing and chatting or enjoying a quiet moment to himself. He is pictured with The Queen and with his wife Camilla, sons Princes William and Harry, their wives Kate and Meghan, and the Cambridge children George, Charlotte and Louis.Chris Jackson, a photographer who has taken pictures of Charles for the last 15 years, shot the latest collection during a year of exclusive access.&nbspOne shot shows Charles beaming as he clutches a four-month-old Louis to his chest in the gardens of Clarence House on a sunny day last September.Another from the same shoot shows Louis in a family group, grabbing a handful of his grandfather&rsquos face as he leans forward from his mother Kate&rsquos grip.Charles, who has George, five, sitting on his knee and is flanked by his giggling wife Camilla, wears an expression of glee mixed with mock pain.Having a quiet moment (Images are part of a set to mark His Royal Highness's 70th birthday) (Image: Chris JacksonGetty Images for Clarence House)In a third, he is again all smiles as he leads the family to the formal opening of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting at Buckingham Palace.The Queen is listening intently to what he is saying, while behind him Camilla and Prince William and Prince Edward&rsquos wife Sophie share lighthearted conversation.Another shows Charles sharing a joke with Prince William and Prince Harry as they mark the 100th anniversary of the RAF with a Buckingham Palace photoshoot in April.&nbspAll three are dressed in their RAF uniforms for a formal shot used in a commemorative stamp.&nbspLaughing with special guests (Images are part of a set to mark His Royal Highness's 70th birthday) (Image: Chris JacksonGetty Images for Clarence House)But in this instant, they are very much stood down - with father grinning and youngest son looking sheepishly into the ground.Mr Jackson said: &ldquoThere is a warmth and affection between father and sons. It&rsquos a fun relationship - there&rsquos banter. They&rsquore all different characters, but they gel well.Mr Jackson said he has never seen Charles as happy as he was for the September Clarence House shot a round a bench.Three-year-old Princess Charlotte swung on his arms and Prince Harry spirited the handkerchief away from the top pocket of his jacket.Prince Charles and family (Images are part of a set to mark His Royal Highness's 70th birthday) (Image: Chris JacksonGetty Images for Clarence House)&ldquoIt was lovely chaos with the children the photographer said. &ldquoHe is a very hands-on grandfather. He was holding hands with George and Charlotte, and bouncing Louis up and down for a long time.&nbsp&ldquoGeorge was very happy on the prince&rsquos knee. They have a great relationship that&rsquos a little more established, as George is a bit older.&ldquoThis is someone with a sense of pride for his family. A sense of pride in what his children are achieving.In another shot from the Commonwealth meeting, Charles is seen laughing with his younger sister Princess Anne, who has her eyes closed and head thrown back in mirth.Marking the RAF's 100th (Images are part of a set to mark His Royal Highness's 70th birthday) (Image: Chris JacksonGetty Images for Clarence House)He also brings a smile to a maid&rsquos face as she offers him milk for his tea in his private sitting room at Dumfries House, Ayrshire, Scotland, last May.Dame Judi Dench is also seen laughing uproariously in his company as the actress attends a reception at Dumfries House with partner David Mills.&ldquoHe has a great sense of humour, Mr Jackson said. &ldquoI think that comes across in a lot of these photographs.&nbsp&ldquoThat&rsquos just him being him. I don&rsquot think it&rsquos something he puts on for the camera, you couldn&rsquot do it across so many facets of your life.'Grandpa Wales' and Louis (Images are part of a set to mark His Royal Highness's 70th birthday) (Image: Chris JacksonGetty Images for Clarence Hous)&ldquoThey see him as very serious, which he is. But I would like people to see the lighter side of him.The collection also shows the Prince working quietly by himself in the Dumfries House sitting room and, sunglasses-clad, in the gardens at Highgrove, near Tetbury, Gloucs.Charles, a passionate environmentalist and champion of British farming, is also seen tipping a bucket of feed out for his Burford brown and Maran chickens at Highgrove.The Queen&rsquos oldest son celebrated his birthday last Wednesday with events culminating in a black tie dinner at Buckingham Palace.Royals at Buckingham Palace (Images are part of a set to mark His Royal Highness's 70th birthday) (Image: Chris JacksonGetty Imagesfor Clarence House)He was saluted by artillery guns, hosted a reception for other people who turned 70 this year, and praised warmly by the Queen at the banquet&ldquoIt is a privilege for any mother to be able to propose a toast to her son on his 70th birthday, she said.&ldquoIt is rather like - to use an analogy I am certain will find favour - planting a tree and being able to watch it grow.

story: BBC host Andrew Marr shut down Shami Chakrabarti after she challenged him on his democratic acceptance of the Brexit referendum results. You&rsquore going to go to a general election campaign as a member of a party whose manifesto says &lsquowe are leaving the EU, we are EU-exit enablers.&rsquoAfter Ms Chakrabarti claimed she would support Labour's plans because she is a democrat, Mr Marr exploded: Don&rsquot try and patronise me. I&rsquom as much a democrat as you are.Ms Chakrabarti explained she still did not want to leave the European Union but respected the will of the people who opted to withdraw from the bloc in the 2016 referendum.She said: I don&rsquot want to leave the EU. To leavers, to Remainers.I&rsquove read it all, thank you.The Labour Party has so far insisted their MPs would vote against the proposed deal unless Theresa May re-enters negotiations with Brussels to change terms that would see Britain enter a UK-wide backstop agreement to avoid the creation of a hard border in Northern Ireland.&nbsp                Brexit bitterness could fester for years, warns former PM Gordon Brown                Jeremy Corbyn insists Party ready to strike improved Brexit with EUThe terms would see the country remain in the customs union but unable to alter the trading rules the bloc abides by and would require the EU giving permission before the UK could withdraw from the temporary arrangement.But Brexiteers fear the European Union could use the alleged loophole to keep Britain in the single market and customs union indefinitely.Brexiteer Nadine Dorries compared the possibility of maintaining close ties to Brussels as serfdom during a scathing attack against both the proposed Brexit withdrawal text and the European Union.The seething Mid Bedfordshire MP said: What the public are absolutely furious about is that the EU have sent this agreement back where they expect us to be slaves to the European Union. We don&rsquot even have the ability to say &lsquocan we leave this extended customs union period?&rsquo They all have to say to us &lsquoyes, you can go.&rsquoYou can use whatever word you want, I would call that a vassal state, an empty state. I&rsquod call it serfdom. It&rsquos appalling and it&rsquos beyond belief that Number 10 think they can sell this to the country. They can&rsquot, people can see right through it.

title: brexit news sell uk cars USA trade deal
story: A RollsRoyce on Rodeo Drive (California) &ndash which have proved a big hit with wealthy Americans (Image: FrankvandenBergh Getty Images)Former Cabinet minister Owen Paterson, who is in Washington with a delegation of MPs, has said his talks with US trade officials last week painted a bleak picture about Britain's opportunities unless the Government delivers a proper Brexit. His concerns come as senior academics say a no deal scenario with the EU is now the best option available for the UK at this late stage. Mr Paterson, a former environment and Northern Ireland secretary, has warned that the PM's deal is so bad it cannot possibly proceed.                'Trump READY for trade deal' claims David Davis                 The PM&rsquos deal would block free trade with the US, says Owen PatersonHe said Mrs May's much-criticised backstop of staying in the customs union and keeping Northern Ireland in the EU's single market could end up being permanent and would be governed by the EU's European Court of Justice.He said: In Washington last week, I discussed the deal with senior US trade representatives. There was real enthusiasm for a USUK trade deal but they were categorical that this would be impossible if the UK does not control its own tariff schedules or regulatory environment. That is exactly the fate which awaits us under the Prime Minister's current plans.Many British luxury brands are popular in the US with Rolls-Royce, which is made here, last year selling almost 2,000 cars, despite the lack of a trade deal. Clothing brands Next, Asos, Lipsy London, Rokit and Sweaty Betty also boast strong sales due to the UK's reputation for quality.Mr Paterson said that Mrs May should not simply stick to what she has secured from the EU.He added: Her best option is to change course and negotiate a wideranging, zero-tariff trade agreement, with solutions to the Northern Ireland border based on existing techniques and processes. Otherwise, she risks failing to honour the largest democratic mandate the British people have ever delivered.Meanwhile, Professor David Paton, chair of industrial economics at Nottingham University Business School, has said poorer voters in Labour heartlands have the most to gain from a no deal with the EU.Owen Paterson (Image: Victoria Jones PA ArchivePA Images)The senior member of Economists for Free Trade and a long-standing Labour member, has said Labour MPs should back Tory Brexiteers in pushing through a no deal if the PM's plans are voted down.Prof Paton pointed out: In the first place, we would no longer be forced to erect huge barriers to trade with non-EU countries, something which forces up the price of food and clothing for hard-pressed consumers. We would be free to strike deals with fast-growing economies around the world and, crucially, we would be able to control economic policy for the benefit of our own workers, consumers and businesses, rather than having to do what works for the EU Commission.He added: Why should we wait until 2022 before the UK is given gracious permission by the EU to abolish VAT on female sanitary products?Professor Gwythian Prins (Image: CH)On the Briefings for Brexit website of pro-Brexit academics, Professor Gwythian Prins has warned that the EU is rapidly collapsing - with economic problems around the euro, its southern economies such as Italy struggling and concerns over Eastern Europe. He said: The Government should have moved away from the rapidly collapsing EU soon after the vote for Brexit two years ago.He also believes that Mrs May's proposed deal is the exact opposite of what people had voted for.He predicted: You cannot negotiate with the EU. We will now leave, to trade with the rest of the world on World Trade Organisation terms.&nbspProfessor David Paton (Image: Youtube)However, the Department for International Trade has insisted that Mrs May's deal will deliver the ability to trade on services, and pacts with the US, Australia and New Zealand can be ratified next year.Services now account for 80 per cent of Britain's export wealth.A DIT spokesman said: The Prime Minister has been clear that once we leave the EU, we will have the ability to negotiate new free trade agreements with the rest of the world. title: Brexit news Nicola Sturgeon Marr Scotland independence UK EU withdrawal latest
story: Nicola Sturgeon tore apart the proposed Brexit deal claiming Theresa May had not considered the plights of Scotland and protecting Scottish interests after leaving the European Union. Ms Sturgeon, a vocal proponent of Scottish independence, in the past hinted she would decide whether to organise a new referendum based on the terms of the final Brexit agreement struck with Brussels. But when asked if she had the guts to officially call for a new vote she said she would wait for the dust to settle.                Sturgeon&rsquos independence hope DISMISSED by Tory MSP who points out FLAWBBC host Andrew Marr challenged the First Minister during The Andrew Marr Show on Sunday: The last time we were talking about this I asked you about another Scottish independence referendum and you said you&rsquod have to wait until you&rsquod seen the withdrawal agreement. You have now seen it, you&rsquore saying you&rsquove read all 585 pages of it.Now you&rsquove seen it what are you going to do?&nbspWhen are you going to have the guts to actually say &lsquoand so therefore we&rsquore going to have another independence referendum?&rsquoThe leader of the SNP was quick to respond: I&rsquoll come on to talk to you, Andrew, as soon as I make that statement.That would be in the not-to-distant future. We have chaos reigning in Westminster just now.READ MORE: David Lidington urges Sturgeon to back Brexit deal for good of ScotlandBrexit news: Marr asked Ms Sturgeon whether she had the guts to call for a new vote (Image: BBC)She continued: I think firstly it is appropriate to wait and see what the House of Commons does with this withdrawal agreement. As things stand just now, it&rsquos not getting the approval of the House of Commons.I will come forward with my views on what I think are the appropriate next steps for Scotland specifically in the not too distant future. But I think it&rsquos reasonable to allow the dust to settle.The implications, the consequences of Scotland not being independent have been very stark in the last few months, and particularly in the last weeks. Scotland&rsquos interests have been sidelined, our Parliament has been ignored.Ms Sturgeon and the SNP had demanded Theresa May consider the option of a bespoke trade agreement for Scotland to mimic a proposed deal for Northern Ireland but the Prime Minister has so far refused her request.&nbsp                May dismantles SNP chief with BRILLIANT point as Commons ROARS                David Lidington urges Sturgeon to back deal for good of ScotlandThe First Minister earlier this week told Scotland's devolved parliament it was reasonable to think the timing of a possible new vote on secession would depend on how Britain's current political chaos over Brexit played out.Ms Sturgeon said: That time will come, and when it does I have no doubt that the people of Scotland will choose to be independent.She likened the deal to being blackmailed into a choice between the frying pan or the fire, claiming it posed a threat to jobs.In a phone call with Theresa May after a five-hour Cabinet meeting on Wednesday, Ms Sturgeon rejected her claim that Scotland's interests had been protected in the deal.The First Minister said: I pointed out that there isn't a single mention of Scotland in the agreement, that it disregards our interests and puts Scotland at a serious competitive disadvantage.&ldquoIt is obvious that the Prime Minister can barely unite her Cabinet on this deal and it is also increasingly clear that she will struggle to get a majority for it in Parliament.In these circumstances, it is more important than ever that we are not faced with a false choice between a bad deal and no deal. No-one should be effectively blackmailed into a choice between the frying pan or the fire.

title: apprentice airline best episode years
story: It split apart million years ago and, must confess, it had entirely escaped my notice before Wednesday night — when it became the fourth-worst ever suggestion for the name of an airline, behind Black Box, Crash Positions and Ryanair.Or it was until Sabrina, from team Collaborative, came up with something that was worse than all of them — Jet Pop Airlines — and added a little explosion in the logo, just to set passengers’ minds fully at rest.No one involved should beat themselves up over any of these decisions, though, as they helped create the best episode of The Apprentice in years.It probably needed to be, as well. I sense, like the recently axed Big Brother and The X Factor, it’s been living off its reputation for a couple of years.Enjoyable as it’s been, the basic issue with this run has been the lack of a central figure in the mould of Syed Ahmed, Katie Hopkins or the late, great Stuart Baggs to take the series by the scruff of the neck.Some have shown vague promise but the closest thing it’s had to an alpha bell-end is Captain Pangea himself, Kurran Pooni, who was marked out less by his all-round uselessness than by the wrist he broke arm-wrestling back at the house, and his insistence he was “ per cent stepping up as project manager” just before he  per cent stepped down.There was no dodging the bullet, though, last week, when Lord Sugar demanded he PM a marketing campaign “for a noo airline” with accompanying adverts “and a noo unorm as well”.Kurran wasn’t underselling the sense of destiny he felt at this responsibility. “Everything in my le has led to this moment,” he claimed, presumably ’cos he hadn’t done anything  up until that moment.The great thing about this task, though — like all the best Apprentice episodes — was that the laughs were shared round equally.So while advert director Kurran was recreating the Club Tropicana video on Southend seafront, Camilla and Jackie were designing a stewardess’s unorm for the party-themed Jet Pop that wouldn’t see the light of day eveneasyJet suddenly opened a brothel chain in Amsterdam.A horrible thought occurred, though, as she was market-researching at Heathrow.She’s not going to wear that thing pitching to  industry experts at BA HQ, is she  She bloody is, you know.She gave it the full doors-to-manual flirtation as well. So everyone’s mind was already in the gutter before Jackie finished the audience off with the news: “It’s very easy to wipe down, as well.”In the normal course of events, reducing Claude Littner to a helpless giggling wreck would be enough to lose any task.The other team, though, Typhoon, had contrived to come up with something almost as bad, Manage Air, a business-targeted operation whose corporate logo looked like a satanic pentangle and theme tune was AC DC’s Highway To Hell.There was a genuine sense of tension in the boardroom then, which would’ve been ruinedSugar had played it all for laughs.He didn’t, though. He let the contestants hang themselves with their own words before firing Kurran, who could leave with a sense of “job done”.He’s created a bit of Apprentice folklore, after all, and hopefully reminded everyone this show is far from dead.Naturally, in the final taxi scene, he also remained convinced of his genius, boldly declaring: “My advert was gold.”The first and possibly last time in his le where he’s not just  per cent wrong, he’s  per cent right as well.Glorious television.Dianne: “Stephen Fry.”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Sesame Street’s Big Bird lives in what street ”Oliver: “I don’t know.”Joe Lycett: “A bird in the hand is worth two in the what ”Jon: “Foot.”And Bradley Walsh: “Which former EastEnders star presents the Sky One series Extreme World ”Zoe: “Barbara Windsor.”CELEBRITY Hunted contestant and former Commando Johnny Mercer MP has faced a stark choice this past month.The eternal humiliation of being beaten by Chris and Kem, off Love Island, on the Channel  hide ’n’ seek game.Or two weeks in a confined space with a clearly smitten Kay Burley.Heroically, he chose the latter, enduring her attention and pet namewith the same sort of grit that probably saw him through three tours of Afghanistan.Then, last week, he sneaked off for an unscheduled visit to his we, Felicity, and Burley completely lost her s***.Lost it so badly, in fact, that she threw herself at the mercy of a passing bread truck driver, which led to the best update of the series: “Kay Burley is currently in a -ton lorry, on the M, between junction  and .”She was quickly grassed up, of course, then apprehended at the Warburton’s depot, without the need for a vet or a tranquilliser dart.But while it’s a poorer show without the old mad-whack, there’s still plenty of mileage left in this gripping series.AJ Pritchard is cornered in Shropshire, Olympic silver medallist Louis Smith has just been found hiding in his mate’s Jacuzzi showroomand Baldrick-brained duo Chris  Kemhave somehow given everyone the slip.But as for Johnny Mercer  He’s probably smuggling himself back to the Mouth of Hell fort, in southern Helmand, just for the relative peace and quiet. Paul Merson: “For me it’s six and a half of one and a dozen of the other.”Graeme Souness: “The only one with potential is Martial and Pogba.”Dion Dublin: “Liverpool are in second and a half gear.”And Charlie Nicholas: “Pogba’s either brilliant or a showpony. He played OK last week.”THIS week’s Doctor Who episode introduced us to the Demons Of The Punjab, who turned out to be nothing of the sort.They were just morbid sods who mope around the universe “honouring those who die alone”, like soldiers, holy men and Brendan O’Carroll on For Facts Sakes.No actual science-fiction storyline to speak of then.But that’s not really the point of this viewer-shedding series, which has already got on its high horse about sexism, Donald Trump, American segregationist racism, men giving birth and gun control.Kind of inevitable, then, that the BBC would eventually pour a bucket of its self-loathing sick all over the British Empire, via the partition of India in , with an episode that was every bit as historically powerful as Carry On Up The Khyber.The key dference, of course, was that Bungdit Din and his Burpers weren’t actually being used as a means of brainwashing children.Because If you were expecting Doctor Who to present the flip side of Britain’s relatively benign rule in India , then you’ll also be waiting for the episode where Jodie Whittaker lands in a Soviet gulag and starts teaching children about the brutal idiocy of Marxism.The BBC just doesn’t do anything other than its own left-of-centre view, these days – or irony by the sounds of things.As it’s just been revealed there’ll be no festive episode of Doctor Whobecause it’s “run out” of storylines.Run out  RUN OUT How the hell can a series run out of ideas when it hasn’t had any yet This Morning, Thursday: “Coming up, at quarter to , the rise of the penis filler, Doctor Ranj is here to answer your questions.”The show’s other penis filler, Martin Lewis, will answer them on Monday.IT seems almost wrong to single out just one programme from Sunday’s beautul Armistice Day coverage, but the year’s most meaningful TV awards should probably all go to BBC’s They Shall Not Grow Old, made by Peter Jackson, whose astonishing film gave a voice, laughter, tears and colour to some of the extraordinary men who survived the - trenches.Those of us who watched it, on Sunday, are unlikely ever to forget the experience. Those of you who didn’t, must catch up with it on the BBC iPlayer.Be sure, though, to watch it right through to the credits’ last chorus of Mademoiselle From Armentières, where it names the veterans who have all long since passed but whose memories and souls have never seemed more alive and unforgettable.“It’s quite hard to put your finger on it.”I’ll bet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: martin lewis free financial education textbook
story: Well, no, actually. It’s far more important than that. Money is an issue of wellbeing.Financial problems are one of the biggest contributors to orce, mental health issues, losing the roof over your head, custody of children and even suicide. And our nation has a real problem with financial capability.That’s why I passionately believe all our children should have financial education at school. While some may say it’s the parents’ responsibility, that doesn’t work when so many parents are struggling to understand financial issues themselves.In , I was involved in leading the successful campaign to get financial education on the English national curriculum, split across Maths and Personal, Social, Health and Economic education .It hasn’t made much dference. The Government put no resources into it.So we kept campaigning. Last year the Government said it would love to see a textbook, but couldn’t or wouldn’t fund it.So I made a donation to cover all costs to the Young Money charity. And last week, , free copies of the first curriculum-mapped financial education textbook Your Money Matters was sent to every English state school .It covers saving, budgeting, borrowing, working, tax, student finance, risk and reward, security and fraud and a lot more. It’s also available as a free PDF.I’ve been surprised at how many grown-ups have downloaded it to go through it with their kids, but ended up telling me they’ve learned something too.Companies spend billions advertising, marketing and teaching their staff to sell, yet we don’t get ANY buyers’ training. story: But there’s something rather wonderful about Donald Trump’s ability to speak the truth, with no frills attached.And not care who he p***es off. Quite right.And he’s right, too, that the EU nations do not pull their weight when it comes to funding the real alliance against our real enemies, Nato.They all like to snipe from the sidelines at the USA.And resent the Americans for their power, influence and success.And for bailing them out of the last war.But then they expect the yanks to spend vast amounts of money protecting them all.Germany, one of the richest countries in the world, spends only . per cent of its GDP on forces for Nato. That is as pathetic as it is typical.The French themselves spend only . per cent.We’re second only to the Americans in our spending — but even then I would argue that it’s not enough.Our Armed Forces have been cut to the bone over the past two decades.Would we be able to retake the Falkland Islands now,Argentina invaded  I doubt it.The truth is that Nato is the one alliance of which we should be glad to be a member.It is an alliance of largely civilised, largely democratic countries which has held fast against tyrants, despots and warmongers for  years.Most notably, of course, the Cold War, in which the Soviet Union was defeated without a shot being fired.But now Trump is getting a bit tired of Nato because the US always has to spend, spend, spend.And with the Europeans thinking again of having an EU army there are many who think the days of Nato are numbered.That would be a terrible mistake.An EU army to replace Nato It would be bureau­cratic, incompetent and short-funded.And it would surrender before you could say “Macron”.THE Lord Mayor of Sheffield is a ludicrous dingbat called Magid Magid who has been coughed up from somewhere deep in the bowels of the Green Party.Shortly before Remembrance Day he posted a publicity shot of himself online wearing a white poppy and a T-shirt saying “never again!”A good moment, then, to ask the vital question: Have you ever met someone wearing a white poppy who wasn’t a complete and utter moron We wear red poppies to commemorate the terrible loss of le in battle.People wear white poppies to commemorate themselves and their fatuous sensibilities.It’s called showing off.WAGES have risen at the fastest rate for almost a decade.They went up by nearly three per cent in the three months to September, compared to a year earlier – and about time, too. This has been the real problem with our economy.But it looks like we’re on the right track.UH-OH – the Beast from the East is said to be on its way back.You remember late last winter. We were snowed in for a week. Nobody could come to visit.The missus couldn’t get to the shops to buy anything.It was just about perfect. All you need is a few bottles of Jack Daniel’s and some soup. Make sure you’re prepared.LUCKY, lucky earthquake victims.Here’s Paris Hilton in Mexico, visiting survivors of the  earthquake.And giving them bottles of Paris Hilton perfume and cushions with “Paris Hilton” stamped across them.Just exactly what they needed.Paris said: “I love the people, I think they are all beautul, they have great hearts, they are beautul inside and out, they are very genuine and incredible.”Just like you, Paris, just like you. A WOMAN who met the Liberal Democrat peer Lord Lester says she was offered an interesting proposition.Have sex with me, the -year-old goat suggested, and I’ll make you a baroness.Can’t say fairer than that, can you The most I’ve ever offered is a bag of Pickled Onion Monster Munch.Lester has been suspended from the House of Lords as a result.Thing is, it’s always the liberals who get up to this kind of stuff.Harvey Weinstein, Kevin Spacey, Woody Allen and now Lester.Ladies, I’m telling you,a liberal bloke approaches you in a bar telling you how pro-feminist he is, activate your alarm, call the Old Bill and get the hell out, sharpish.THIS is Sophie Michelle. She makes £k a year by whispering to people over the internet.Usually stuff like: “Hello sweetheart.”She says it stimulates the listener’s “autonomous sensory meridian response”.Which is perhaps the longest phrase for “penis” I have ever heard.MONICA LEWIN­SKY was the young intern who had an affair with President Clinton, back in the s.Come on – you remember. According to reports a cigar was involved.And Monica had a revealing stain on the front of her dress.She’s been talking about the whole episode again.And she says she thought the stuff on her dress was “spinach dip”.Really  If it looked like spinach dip I think Bill should have got himself off to a doctor, pronto.Are you sure it wasn’t cock-a-leekie ASIA BIBI is the Pakistani Christian woman who was sentenced to death for alleged “blasphemy” against the Prophet Muhammad.She then had her sentence commuted and some Pakistani Muslims are going bonkers, as usual.Demanding she have her head cut off. Threatening to kill anyone who supports her.We should give the poor woman asylum in our country, away from the Islamist savages in Pakistan.But the Government fears “reprisal” attacks by the extremists.That’s a gutless response and devoid of ­principle.Give Asia Bibi a home here. We’ll deal with the savagesthey try ­anything on.We’re getting used to it, after all.I’M trying to work out which of the Remoaners I dislike more. Gary Lineker or Tony Blair.I suppose Gary didn’t illegally invade a sovereign country.But then Blair never sported a stupid goatee beard or spent half of his le selling crisps.Although I daresay he would have donethere’d been enough dosh in it.Lineker, like many other remoaners, was demanding a second vote on Brexit. A People’s Vote.Yep, we’ll do that.Just as soon as we can replay football matches because I don’t like the original score.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit deal purgatory leavers remainers
story: It’s quite a challenge, but let’s have a go.Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Britain ended up with all the costs and obligations of European Union membership, but with no voice, no vote and no veto.Suppose we had to accept all the EU’s rules — on technical standards, on environmental protection, on labour law — but no longer had any say over what those rules should be. Suppose we had to submit to a trade and tarf regime designed solely to benefit the other .I hope both sides could agree that such an outcome would be the worst of all possible worlds. And yet, that is where we appear to have ended up.First, under the transition, we shall explicitly be non-voting members for two years.As Brussels has spelt out with brutal clarity, the only change will be that Britain loses its Commissioner, its MEPs and its vote in Council.Then, under the backstop, that status, or something very like it, will be imposed on us in semi-perpetuity.Surely no one — Remain or Leave — can favour such an outcome.I have been arguing since polling day for moderation.I was prepared to accept any compromise, including European Free Trade Association and including Chequers, provided it restored the supremacy of our laws.But the purgatory that now beckons is surely, by any definition, worse than either staying or leaving.From the start, our objective was simply to reach a deal — any deal.Our negotiators, shell-shocked by the referendum result, approached the talks in a spirit of damage limitation.They never seriously contemplated walking away, and the other side smelt their desperation.To be fair, our officials were not helped by the noises coming out of Westminster.How would you expect EU negotiators to react when senior British politicians urge them to hang tough and force a second referendum We might view Tony Blair, John Major and Nick Clegg as has-beens but, believe me, they are seen in Brussels as men of influence.So we fell into a pattern. Britain would make some new concession in the hope of unlocking a deal.Then Brussels would pocket the concession and demand more and — incredibly — British Remainers would cheer.The UK agreed to hand over more money than was due accepted the EU’s absurd and illogical sequencing made an unconditional security guarantee offered to copy EU standards and promised not to be more competitive than its neighbours.Each time, the EU brusquely demanded “more movement”. Each time, Britain rushed to comply.Which brings us to where we are — facing colonial rule from Brussels, of the sort the EU imposed on Bosnia following the Yugoslav war.I am not one of those Brexiteers who half-favoured no deal all along.On the contrary, I was proposing moderation even before the vote, and have repeated that call many times since.But, paradoxically, our reluctance to countenance no deal has made such an outcome likelier.We have reached the point where the terms on offer are less attractive than either a World Trade Organization-based Brexit or a second referendum. This last point is critical.I suspect that two contradictory arguments will now be wheeled out before wavering MPs.Europhiles will be told that the deal, backstop and all, is better than “crashing out” on WTO terms.Conversely, Eurosceptics will be told thatthey don’t approve the deal, Parliament might vote to extend Article , thus imperilling Brexit.These two lines of argument can’t both be true, of course and, in reality, neither of them is.We’re invited to believe thatBoris Johnson and Jo Johnson, from opposite ends of the Brexit spectrum, both oppose the deal, it can’t be too bad. In fact, both Johnsons oppose it because it is a lamentable failure of statecraft.Boris was no Brexit headbanger: He came out for Leave only after the EU refused to give David Cameron any powers back.And Jo is no Remoaner: He has spent two years in Government trying to deliver a reasonable Brexit. If neither of them will back the deal, that tells us something.There is still time — just — to recover our position.As things stand, the backstop has no legal force.The moment it finds its way into a treaty, it will be binding. If any MPs oppose the current approach, now is their chance to act. There won’t be another.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: time for decades of eu lies to end
story: Britain is a eurosceptic nation. In the s, Ted Heath and Harold Wilson both knew we would baulk at belonging to a Common Market that robbed us of our national independence.So they hid its true purpose — “ever closer union”, leading to a superstate with one currency. The public was reassured our sovereignty would not be surrendered to any meaningful degree.The Tory and Labour leaders both knew this was a lie. But they kept quiet when signing us up in  and when holding the first referendum in .Voters were betrayed from the start. And the pattern was set.In  John Major signed the Maastricht Treaty, creating the EU, without risking the public vote that saw it initially rejected by the Danes and Irish.In  Tony Blair — who now shamelessly praises fork-tongued civil ­servants for hoodwinking eurosceptic ministers — feared he would lose a referendum on handing new powers to the EU. So he refused to hold it.His successor Gordon Brown, never big on honesty when a lie served him better, pretended this Lisbon Treaty was too insignicant to bother voters with.The EU is founded on deceit. “When it becomes serious, you have to lie,” says President Jean-Claude Juncker. Voters are bullied into reversing inconvenient referendums or denied a say at all.And so to Mrs May, the Brexit deal her Cabinet agreed last night and the revealing EU leak yesterday which makes crystal-clear Brussels’ intentions to keep us in its vice-like grip for ever.That plan being to lock us into its Customs Union for all time, unable to make our own trade deals, powerlessly swallowing its orders and obeying its rules.Our Government knows we cannot legally escape this central pillar of the EU — which we voted to “leave”, remember — without consent from Brussels that it will never give.This is not some minor afterthought, to be bargained away, which is why MPs rejected it in July. It is crucial to the reclaiming of our sovereignty which a .million majority including many Sun readers, voted for in .It is crucial to our post-Brexit prosperity. It looks crucial, too, to whether the deal lives or dies. Yet, knowing exactly what the EU intends for us, the PM still brazenly insisted yesterday that we WILL make our own trade deals.How, Mrs May  We cannot. You surely know it.Do not kid yourself no one is paying attention. The public has been sold a pup again and again. It has had enough.Come clean with Britain. This deal is not wholly without merit. But let us see it for what it is.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: costa coffee christmas toasties labels
story: Complaints flooded in after the coffee giant launched its festive range three weeks ago.On the packet, the sandwich is billed as theUltimate Christmas Toastie, with sweet cranberry sauce on cheese-topped bread.Based on this description, veggie customers bought and ate the toastie before noticing it contained bacon and turkey.But this information is only disclosed on the back of the packaging, which is removed and thrown out by staff to heat the toastie, reports Somerset Live.A picture of the packet was posted on Twitter by Nazya Fiaz, who wrote: Major labelling issues!!! this toastie had turkey slices! However, no mention on the front packaging. Why    Shipley Costa.After two days Costa apologised for any confusion and said the fridge labels had been updated to highlight that the toastie contains meat.But it was not the first time a customer had flagged up the issue.Tracey from London said: Costa Coffee yesterday I stopped at my local Costa to have a light bite to eat and choose the ultimate Christmas cheese toastie.I was nearly sick as someone who doesnt eat pork found after the first bite it had bacon and turkey in, totally ruined my experience. Not happy.Its all about the information, nothing on the front of packaging letting the consumer know what meat was in the product.It also has bacon in it and I havent eaten pork for over  years. The front of the packaging should state what meat is contained. What is Costa Coffee going to do about it  Just saying sorry is not acceptable!!”Drew White also pointed out the issue saying: Contains Christmas with cranberry sauce on cheese topped bread.Something missing from this description I feel!Costa Coffe said of the toastie on Twitter: It contains British turkey cheese-topped toastie with maple smoked bacon, sage and onion and cranberry sauce.But a customer pointed out that it was odd that the word turkey doesnt appear on it”.Despite Costa Coffee saying they updated their fridge labels, it has not appeared in all stores yet.

title: sainsburys edible insects roasted crickets
story: From Sunday,  of the chain’s stores will exclusively stock Eat Grub’s Smoky BBQ Crunchy Roasted Crickets.The packets of crickets, which will retail at £. each are described as “crunchy in texture with a rich smoky flavour” and “packed with protein”.The supermarket says the crickets can be “eaten alone as a tasty snack or used to garnish dishes such as tacos, noodles or salads”.Rachel Eyre, Head of Future Brands at Sainsbury’s, said: “Insect snacks should no longer be seen as a gimmick or something for a dare, and it’s clear that consumers are increasingly keen to explore this new sustainable protein source.“We’re always looking to provide our customers with new and exciting products, and with the growing interest in edible insects we’re excited to be the first UK supermarket to make these products easily accessible for shoppers across the country.”While insects have been available to buy in specialist shops as well as online grocer’s Ocado, this is the first time a high street supermarket has stocked them.Insects are said to have nutritional benefits with dried crickets, gram for gram, containing more protein than beef, chicken and pork.Just g of crickets contains g of protein, compared to g of beef, according to the British Nutrition Foundation.Eat Grub co-founder Shami Radia said: “Currently Insects are eaten and enjoyed by two billion people worldwide.“We’re on a mission to show the West that as well as having very strong sustainability and environmental credentials, they are also seriously tasty and shouldn’t be overlooked as a great snack or recipe ingredient.“Insects can produce the same amount of protein for a fraction of the land, water and feed used to rear traditional livestock. What’s more, insects are estimated to release % less methane than cows.”Eat Grub was founded in  by friends Radia and Neil Whippey.

title: imam recites muslim call to prayer during a church of england cathedrals armistice concert without permission
story: Video of the imam wearing a white robe was taken last Saturday at Blackburn Cathedral and posted on the internet.The call to worship was part of a performance of Karl Jenkins’ The Armed Manin the nave of the cathedral, organised by the Blackburn Music Society.The second movement is a traditional Muslim call to worship recited in Arabic and the imam was chosen to deliver it by the Blackburn with Darwen Interfaith Forum.Speaking in Arabic, the imam said: Allah is the greatest I bear witness that there is no other God but Allah I bear witness that Muhammad is the messenger of Allah.The recitation was made as part of a concert to commemorate the armistice and was reportedly carried out without the churchs permission.Peter Howell-Jones, the dean of Blackburn Cathedral, told The Sunday Times: “I dont think this should have happened here.If people are going to call for my resignation theres nothing more I can say or do to people to pacy them because actually I agree with their arguments.If the booking was made now the answer would be . . . you are very welcome to do the piece but not the call to prayer bit, he added.According to the Sunday Times he only realised that the Muslim call to prayer was in the piece shortly before it began at .pm and did not want to upset anyone by removing it.Lord Carey, a former Archbishop of Canterbury, said it was important for Christianity and Islam to get on together as world faiths.He said “let’s not make too much of a fuss about it but added “I don’t think that without permission I have any right to go into a mosque and preach a Gospel sermon…and I would make that as a parallel”.

title: madeleine mccann parents meeting with scotland yard detectives to discuss two vital new leads
story: Last week the Home Office confirmed they had provided the politan Police with another £, to chase a “final line of inquiry”.Scotland Yard have been applying for funds every six months to continue the inquiry - known as Operation Grange - that has cost £.million so far.In a sit-down meeting last week with the McCanns the Operation Grange team told them they had “two specic and active” lines of inquiry.A Whitehall source told the Daily Mail: “politan Police officers had a sit-down meeting with Madeleines parents to tell them exactly where they were with their inquiries.“They informed them they had two specic and active leads that still needed to be chased and that although the investigation was taking longer than they initially thought officers said they were confident and hopeful they could get a result.”A senior Government source added: “Police seeking special grant funding have needed to justy exactly what the money would be spent on, who they are chasing and why.“They have had to outline their intended work in full detail and careful consideration has been given but we cannot ulge any aspects of that while there is an ongoing operation.”Madeleine was three when she was last seen while on holiday with her parents in Praia da Luz, Portugal, in May .Former GP Kate and heart doctor Gerry, both , from Rothley in Leicestershire, are “very encouraged” the politan Police could finally be closing in on Maddie’s kidnapper after eleven-and-a-half years.Family spokesman Clarence Mitchell said: “They are very encouraged that the Met Police still believe there is work left to be done in the search for their daughter and they remain incredibly grateful to the Home Office for providing an extra budget for the investigation.It is a boost the while family and gives them renewed hope that one day they may finally find out what happened to Madeleine.Devastated parents of other missing children slammed that decision and questioned why the McCanns were getting “priority treatment”.Paul Whinham, , from Wallsend in North Tyneside, has been searching for his -year-old son Michael for three years.Speaking to the Sun Online he said: “After a six month investigation the Chief Inspector of Northumbria Police told me ‘I’m sorry Paul there’s no more money to keep on going, the case is closed butyou want to declare your son dead it takes six years’.“If any new evidence comes to light,there’s any more sightings or anything, I was told to get in touch with them.”He added: “But then I find out yet another £, is going from the Home Office to the politan Police to keep Operation Grange going.“Even police have said there’s no other evidence, there’s nothing that’s come to light in  years. Why  Why are they keeping going  Why “Why is one family getting all this priority  There are , missing people in this country.”In a separate case Karen Downes, , said she felt “very angry” other children, including her daughter Charlene, were “simply being forgotten”.She told the Sun Online: “A child goes missing in the UK every three minutes. What about all those others who never come home again ”No trace has been found of Charlene, , since she was last seen in Blackpool on November ,  – despite huge publicity and a £, reward.Last year detectives finally released the only CCTV footage of her on the day she vanished - after it lay unnoticed on police shelves for  years.Two takeaway workers were acquitted of her murder in  after a trial heard her body was chopped up and had gone into kebabs.Karen added: If they are going to plough money into the search for Madeleine, then they should do the same for all the children who are missing.She didn’t even go missing in this country – it’s really a matter for the Portuguese police, and yet the money just keeps on rolling in for the search.”Ben Needham’s mum, Kerry, has previously criticised the cash given to the Maddie search, saying it “hurt her”.She said: As Bens mum Im not taking anything away from them. We havent had a fraction of that help.Operation Grange has been one of the longest, most high-profile and costly police investigations in history.Some  persons of interest have been examined and sightings of Madeleine — in Brazil, India, Morocco and Paraguay, on a German plane and in a New Zealand supermarket — assessed.Previously police confirmed they thought Maddie was snatched by a paedophile gang who may have smuggled her over the border or grabbed during a botched burglary at the holiday complex.They have also been keen to identy a woman in purple seen hanging around the holiday flat.The Portuguese investigation of Madeleines disappearance was criticised by the British authorities as being not fit for purpose.Scotland Yard began an investigative review into the disappearance in , on the orders of then-Prime Minister David Cameron.Not one piece of forensic evidence linked to the little girl has been found since she vanished.And despite trawling through thousands of tip-offs and potential sightings, police have not confirmed that a single one was her.A Scotland Yard spokesman confirmed: “We have confirmed that Special Grant funding of £, will be provided to the politan Police Service for the six-month period to  March . This is an ongoing police investigation.”

title: esther mcvey cabinet meltdown brexit deal
story: The ex-Pensions Secretary reportedly became hysterical as she slammed Theresa Mays Brexit plan.Ms McVey today denied that she lost her temper - and described Cabinet colleagues as feeble for getting alarmed by her behaviour.The MP for Tatton resigned on Thursday morning, slamming the PM over the proposed withdrawal agreement.During the crunch Cabinet meeting the day before, Ms McVey was the angriest minister - urging Mrs May to let those present take a formal vote on whether or not they back the deal.One Cabinet source told the Mail on Sunday: It was the most extraordinary meltdown Ive seen in Cabinet.I thought security would have to be called, because she seemed so hysterical and aggressive.Chief Whip Julian Smith ended up shouting at her to shut up, the minister added.Ms McVey today described the claims as hilarious and mocked ministers for overreacting.She said: Seems a bit of straight talking from me to ask Cabinet members to vote on the most important matter in a letime made them crumble!Makes you wonderthis is how feeble senior members have been in negotiations with the EU over our future After she demanded a vote on the deal, Cabinet Secretary Mark Sedwill - Britains top civil servant - produced documents showing that a formal vote is impossible.Ms McVey was one of two Cabinet ministers to resign on Thursday, triggering a massive crisis for Mrs May.The PM is now fighting off an attempt to call a vote of no confidence in her leadership.

title: thousands of worms being blasted into space to find secret to a longer healthier life
story: The tiny transparent worms will be heading to the International Space Station as part of a Government-backed project to seetwo drugs can prevent or slow down muscle wasting brought on by microgravity.Worms are being used because they have a similar muscle structure to humans.They suffer from muscle loss in many of the same conditions that humans do.In space, the mm long c-elegans worms will have nothing to push against to keep their muscle mass and so quickly start losing strength.This mirrors the impact experienced by the elderly on Earth and those with conditions like muscular dystrophy and diabetes.Experts at Nottingham University are hoping that by either boosting the cell batteries or improving their uptake of calcium will mean they can slow down the process or even prevent it entirely.Dr Bethan Phillips, assistant professor at the university, said: We know that microgravity accelerates the effects of muscle disuse similar to when elderly people are bedbound or are recovering from an injury.Skeletal muscle is linked to many systems in the body, such as the immune system, so the health implications are not just loss of movement, they are far more widespread.The worms have similar muscle to human skeletal muscle so we can seethese pharmaceuticals have a beneficial effect which could eventually lead to new treatments both for astronauts and the elderly.Not only do these experiments offer hope for the elderly on Earth but they will be vital to the success of future colonies on the Moon or Mars.Astronauts can lose up to  per cent of muscle mass on a y mission and . per cent of their bone mass for each month spent in space.Tim Peake was missing nearly  per cent of his bone volume by the time he touched down from his trip aboard the ISS.The experiment is one of several being funded by the UK Space Agency, which has provided nearly £million ahead of the th anniversary of the International Space Station on Tuesday.The government says tackling ageing is one of its grand challenges and it wants to add five extra health years of le by .A team from Liverpool will also be sending tubes of human muscles grown from stem cells to the ISS to seeheat shock proteins could stop the inevitable decline of muscles.In the cells of older people muscles fail to get stronger even when they exercise, which researchers believe could be because of inflammation in the body.Researchers believe the heat shock proteins may help dampen down the impact.Professor Malcolm Jackson, from the University of Liverpool, said: Ageing is one of the greatest challenges of the st century and so the opportunity to use micro gravity to help understand the mechanisms underlying age-related muscle loss is really exciting.There is some evidence that inflammation is behind the problems with ageing muscle andwe can find a way to stop that inflammatory response it could be beneficial.Sending cells into microgravity allows us to look at muscle ageing response in isolation without the other effects of ageing complicating the pictures.The University of Strathclyde in Glasgow will also receive nearly £. million to investigate how shaking a liquid in microgravity includes solid particles to accumulate and from highly ordered aggregates, instead of causing the floating particles to simply disperse.Science Minister Sam Gyimah said: This research will help those with muscle conditions to live longer, healthier, happier lives and is a great example of our modern industrial strategy in action - transforming le on earth through out-of-this-world research.

title: david cameron prime minister brexit steve hilton
story: The ex-PM could make a comebackhis successor is forced to stand down, according to his former guru.Steve Hilton, Mr Camerons director of strategy, said his old boss could be the best hope for Britain.He suggested one reason the Brexit process has been so tricky is that Mr Cameron quit immediately after the EU referendum.Writing in the Sunday Times, Mr Hilton said: What Britain needs above all is a leader with the confidence and the character to command respect and bring people together from all sides of this bruising two-year national meltdown.If there is a Conservative party leadership election, no doubt many able MPs will throw their hat in the ring.But there’s one name that should also be on the list - David Cameron.Considering where we are now, David Cameron’sto No could in fact be the best hope for Britain.Mr Hilton blasted Mrs Mays proposed Brexit deal - but claimed it would have been almost impossible to negotiate a better one.Instead he called for Britain to leave the EU without any deal, and use it as an opportunity to re-imagine the countrys economy.The Sun revealed earlier this month that Mr Cameron is keen toto frontline politics because hes bored s***less.The former Prime Minister left Parliament in , a few months after leaving Downing Street.But he likes the idea of making an unexpected comeback, possibly in the key role of Foreign Secretary.

earlier this year.Payton said she was aware of those claims but was “not sure who was telling the truth”.She said she had applied on the website but the process was “very tedious and long” so she pulled out, which she now realised was a “good decision as something could’ve gone wrong”.She reached out to another woman for advice, a -year-old student from Brazil who told media in August she was auctioning her virginity for £, .Payton said: “I found her off an article, I went to her web page and emailed her on there,”“I was asking her questions, asking her advice on how to start. She told me, you know, ‘Make a web page, make sure you set up the details correctly, know what you’re looking for.’”Payton copied the layout and much of the text from the other woman’s website.One section reads: “I don’t care about the age or the appearance of a man.“I admire respectful and intelligent men. Men who take care of women, give compliments and know what they want. I will be waiting for you to take my innocence.”It also lists a series of rules for the process, stating that “documents of my virginity will be provided by local health authorities”, the buyer “also has the further possibility to check me up again with a doctor he trusts” and “we will spend  hours together at the hotel where the winner is staying”.Payton said she didn’t want to ask her parents, who are originally from South America, for any financial help and would “probably” never tell them.She said: “I think they would think it’s kind of stupid, I don’t think they would get angry, they would just ask me why I would do something like that.“I guess I’d lie . I would just say I got a job.”Dr Lauren Rosewarne, senior social scientist at the University of Melbourne and author of Intimacy on the Internet, said she didn’t see it as “either positive or negative”.She said: “At the end of the day it’s up to a woman how she uses her body, andshe wants to profit from selling access to her virginity that’s her choice.“I do think it says something about our culture that the quickest way for a woman to earn , upwards is to do this.“Just be careful.

title: mirror possessed ghost titanic captain for sale
story: The -year-old antique is believed to be possessed by the ghost of Edward John Smith - who left it on his dressing table before setting sail on the ill-fated ocean liners maiden voyage.His servant Ethelwynne took it from his home in lieu of wages after the ship was sunk by an iceberg on  April, .The terried maid claimed she could see the Captains face appear in it every year on the anniversary of the Titanics sinking.It was passed down by her relatives before being abandoned in Wolverhampton and picked up by current owner David Smith - who kept it locked in a vault for five years.Included with the mirror is a small brown envelope containing a handwritten note about the mirrors past.Ethelwynnes sister-in-law wrote to a pal: She always spooked me when she said that at times she could still see Captain Smith’s face in it on the anniversary of when the Titanic was sunk.Auctioneer Richard Winterton said: “The last time Captain Edward John Smith saw his own noble, bearded visage before leaving home to take the helm of the Titanic was possibly in this very mirror.“Even with one’s feet firmly on land and in the sunshine of a clear afternoon, there is something otherworldly about seeing your own reflection in such an object.“Captain Smith must have surveyed his own image in this mirror countless times and the legend that his face can still be seen in it on each anniversary of the Titanic’s sinking is as compelling as it is chilling!Whoever buys this in December will have it in good time to test that legend for themselves on the th anniversary next April.”The mirror is expected to fetch more than £, when it goes up for auction in Lichfield, Staffs.Dickinson’s Real Deal star Richard Winterton said: Interest in the Titanic is as strong as ever. This mirror could fetch well in excess of £, at auction.
